Next up – getting our bill through the Senate and signed into law!

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text:
“Section 127 echo” and “Section 1202” provide U.S. funds to partner with foreign military forces to combat terrorism and conduct irregular warfare.

There is no statutory requirement for these partners to be vetted.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text:
Our amendment closes an important loophole in the landmark “Leahy Law” – which passed over two decades ago and ensured our military aid doesn’t go to those who have committed gross human rights violations.

Currently, two key Pentagon programs skirt this law.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text:
On Tuesday, I introduced the Upholding Human Rights Abroad Act. Today, the House passed it as part of an amendment to NDAA.

This is a huge win for human rights and accountable U.S. military aid. 🧵

tweet_text: And in the last year we have seen the threat morph from a violent mob to a more insidious effort to use the institutions themselves to overturn the will of the people – and those threats to our democracy are real.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: I never thought the most dangerous place I could be was the United States Capitol. But on January 6, the United States Capitol became a conflict setting.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: Before coming to Congress, I worked at the United Nations and the State Department. I’d worked on post-coup transitions and responses to violent extremism and electoral violence in places around the world. I’d been in scary situations before.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: I’ll never forget waiting for the elevator door to open, sure we were going to see a machine gun, and for it all to be over.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: Fashioning weapons out of stanchions and pens and my high heels, ready to take on the rioters who were banging on the doors behind us. Climbing over chairs and under rails not sure where the rioters were.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: I’ll never forget the buzzing of the escape hoods. The fear when I couldn’t open the packaging. The sound of the doors closing and being locked.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: I still didn’t know how to get around the Capitol building and I’d never even been in the Gallery before, which I would come to learn was totally cut off from the rest of the Chamber – and from the emergency exits.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: January 6 was my fourth day in office. I, like many of my colleagues, was watching the certification of the election results from the House Gallery because of COVID protocols.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text:
I just walked into the @January6thCmte hearing. I'm sitting with the same colleagues I was trapped with in the House Gallery on January 6.

We deserve to know the truth about what happened that day, who was involved, and how we are going to hold them accountable. 🧵...

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: As a member of the House Armed Services Committee, I have been incredibly frustrated by a lack of transparency and a lack of accountability at the Pentagon on civilian casualties. The process is broken and we need major reforms.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: This is a major problem and has been for a long time. One of our very last military actions in Afghanistan was a drone strike that killed 10 civilians and targeted a vehicle that was not a threat.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: 🧵Civilian casualties are a moral stain on our military operations and are counterproductive to our security goals. When we kill civilians, we’re not only taking innocent life, we’re recruiting another generation to take up arms against us.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text:
Russia has a track record of not mitigating civilian harm in Syria and elsewhere and has been accused in the past of targeting civilians. We're seeing the same story in Ukraine. 

That's why we must prepare a robust humanitarian response and ensure safe haven to those fleeing. https://t.co/mewAdxTt5a

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: It’s understandable to want to do more. But we must understand what is at stake. The risks of two nuclear powers going to war are dramatically increased by a no-fly zone. This is unimaginable, and would risk many more civilian casualties than a no-fly zone would save.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: And if Russia retaliated, as they certainly would, our Article 5 obligation would be triggered – and the U.S. would be at war with Russia.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: This would mean the U.S. declaring war on Russia. The same goes for if a NATO ally were to enforce the no-fly zone. They too might have to shoot down Russian jets.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: A no-fly zone is enforced, not declared. It requires our fighter jets to go directly against Russian fighter jets, to get them to stay out of a certain airspace. If the U.S. were to do this, our fighter jets would potentially have to shoot down Russian jets.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text:
The U.S. & NATO are united in our support for Ukraine. It's the right thing to do in the face of Russian aggression —but we need to be smart about how we do that.

A no-fly zone seems simple, even the bare minimum to save lives. But let’s talk through what this actually means. 🧵

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: I was in middle school when the decision to invade Afghanistan was made and I did not have a say. Now, as a Member of the House Foreign Affairs and Armed Services Committees, I am committed to ensuring we learn the lessons of the last few months, and the past twenty years.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: There are many reasons for the challenges we are seeing in Afghanistan today, most of which predate the current President, and they deserve a fulsome policy debate.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: The United States has a moral obligation to help the Afghan people. We also owe them, and all those who sacrificed, honesty and humility about the real failures in Afghanistan over the past twenty years.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: We must guarantee humanitarian parole, increase the refugee cap & provide assistance to refugees, ensure legal safeguards & funding for organizations that deliver humanitarian assistance, and evacuate as many Americans & vulnerable Afghans as possible before we withdraw.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: And while I am disappointed in the execution of the withdrawal and committed to assessing the policy failures in Afghanistan, right now, I am focused on getting as many people to safety as possible and responding to the humanitarian needs of people in Afghanistan.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: I continue to support and agree with President Biden’s decision to withdraw from Afghanistan. However, I remain incredibly concerned about the ongoing evacuation process in Kabul and the deteriorating humanitarian situation in Afghanistan.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: My bill would repeal this 25% cap, and call on @POTUS to advocate for needed reforms at the UN. This is a quick policy fix that would have a huge impact on U.S. credibility, the financial health of the UN, and advancement of important reform.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: In 2018, China and Russia successfully lobbied for the Human Rights Upfront Initiative to be disbanded. This was an important initiative to the U.S. that strengthened and prioritized human rights in UN engagements.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: These dues have also diminished our standing at the UN. It creates a leadership vacuum and undermines our ability to push for accountability and reform efforts – including human rights initiatives – at the UN.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: Many developing nations that provide the bulk of peacekeeping troops aren't fully reimbursed for their contributions. These shortfalls amount to tens of millions of dollars each for developing nations like Bangladesh, Ghana, and Tanzania.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: Did you know that Congress established a 25% cap on contributions to #UNPeacekeeping in 1994? Our actual share of funding that we have agreed to at the UN is a little over 27%, meaning we are constantly in debt to the UN. The impact?

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: This week, I introduced the U.S. Commitment to Peacekeeping Act, a bill to make sure the United States fulfills our commitments to the United Nations.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text:
In #CA53, more than 148,000 kids live in households that will receive the Child Tax Credit — that’s 84% of all the kids in our district. 

44,600 households will receive an average benefit of $2,900. That’s 12,400 kids who will no longer experience poverty.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: Nationwide, the expanded Child Tax Credit is projected to cut childhood poverty in half, lifting 5 million American children out of poverty.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: If you filed your 2020 taxes, you don’t have to do anything to apply. And for the families that didn’t file a 2020 tax return, the IRS created a non-filer tool that will automatically determine your eligibility and get you set up to receive the payments. https://t.co/if10YpNpFm

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: Now, starting next month, families across the country will start receiving monthly payments directly into their bank accounts or mailboxes — up to $300 per child per month.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: The #ChildTaxCredit means a tax cut for working families all across the country. As Jeffrey Hoehn of @CLNkids said, “Single mothers know where every penny goes. They just don’t have enough pennies to go around.” That goes for so many working parents in #CA53.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: We say “expanded and improved” because we increased the CTC from $2,000 up to $3,000 per kid per year — and up to $3,600 per kid under 6. And we also made sure more lower-income families are eligible.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: After I was elected, I fought to have the expanded and improved #ChildTaxCredit included in the final package of the American Rescue Plan because of the huge impact it would have for families with kids.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: President Biden was right: you can always find reasons to stay — but the fact is, wars are supposed to end. It’s past time for this one.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: An important point was made by the President during his remarks— we’ll continue to work through diplomatic and humanitarian channels to support the people of Afghanistan. This is the appropriate next step as we continue to uphold democracy and human rights.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: I was in middle school when we went to war in Afghanistan. I’m now a Member of Congress, serving on the Armed Services and Foreign Affairs Committees. It feels surreal to react to this news and recognize just how long we have been at war.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: And as someone who represents a proud military community in San Diego, I’ve heard from families with two generations of servicemembers who have served in Afghanistan and two generations of families who have supported and sacrificed with them.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: President Biden visiting Arlington this afternoon underscores the gravity of the choices that the Commander in Chief has to make. And that Congress has abdicated for too long.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: I know this is a complicated day for those who served in Afghanistan—who lost loved ones and still live with the trauma of war. A lot of American soldiers died even as our govt and our people lost faith in the efforts. We should never forget that and never let it happen again.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
tweet_text: Watching @POTUS’s remarks on Afghanistan in my DC office between hearings and votes today. This is a historic moment and it’s clear that the President recognizes the importance of this decision. After 20 years, our longest war is ending, and it’s ending this year.
